history.content: Uh, software engineering? Not sure why people are telling you to go towards finance (unless they mean quant), but even then quant is very high-risk high-reward as we have seen in recent events.

children.subject: Oh gotcha, to be honest if you do have multiple offers and can afford to be picky between companies in these fields, I would choose the one you feel you will enjoy working at the most, and secondly which one has the highest future earning potential. Out of all those fields you listed I think they all have good companies so it really just comes down to what you want to do. If you want to know what I am personally doing, I will be interning in the ML/AI field this summer and later hope to try out quant, not too sure yet for new grad. Hope this was helpful :)

Oh yes! Sorry I should have clarified. I meant like for example, doing software engineering in a fintech field (so like banks, or investment companies), vs doing SWE in.. idk, transportation, so like autonomous cars, or maybe in more of a business field, like CRM or something. Does that make sense?

I dont know what year you are, but there is a huge variety of topics. There are cryptography/security courses, pure CS theory, obviously ML, computer architecture/digital design, signal processing, robotics, IC design, just to name a few. The EE/CS/EECS offerings at this school are pretty large and many courses are interdisciplinary. You might wanna shop around on the course catalog for the EE and CS courses and see what you might be interested in. Look at some of the websites if possible, maybe check out the piazza forums as well, most are open. Its a shame that its hard to gauge interests with just the lower divs (to the fault of no one). I think the 16 series gives people a real sour taste for EE courses, even though the upper divs are nothing like those 2 courses. Also there is a quant finance decal that is still taking applications I believe if you want to check that out as well. 

When your early in your college career, you might think you want to do something, but you might take a class that will lead you down another path. The only way to know is to do some self-research into the courses, and try some out! As a tip from a graduating senior, don't think too hard about the "i dont know what im going to do with my life" stuff, it only gets in the way. Your in a CS program at one of the top universities in the world. You'll be fine, just take courses in what comes naturally. You'll be able to pivot into almost anything else you want down the line should you feel the need. Good luck.
Don't go into fintech. Robinhood and Citadel are evil companies that do borderline illegal things (as are the other hedge funds like Citron, Melvin Capital, etc).

history.content:
What's a good field to go into with a CS degree? What are you guys doing?

I myself have no idea what I'm going to do with my life. Most people tell me to go towards finance, but, I just don't really find the subject interesting and it seems like work-life balance in that field isn't the best. Although I understand its lucrativeness and thus its appeal to people. So I'm wondering what are some other fields that are fulfilling, stable, and can make money?

Also I'm just talking CS degree in general, nothing specific like cybersecurity or machine learning or anything like that.
history.subject: What's a good field to go into with CS?
